    The Six Thinking Hats is a concept that the human mind has different modes of thinking and one could choose the best mode and switch the mode. There are also {"cmd":"url","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Thinking_Hats","desc":"sequences"} for common thinking activities. {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.amazon.com/Six-Thinking-Hats-Edward-Bono/dp/0316178314","desc":"ğŸ”— Amazon"}
    Comparison to Six Archetypes
    The color of the six thinking hats do not match our normal color for the six archetypes, and the thinking modes are scrambled.
    Big Picture/Managing: Herald
    Facts and Information: Alchemist / Herald
    Feelings & Emotions: Cleric / Herald
    Negative: Oracle
    Positive: Magician
    New Ideas: Alchemist
    Instinct/Intuition: Paladin
    Moral: Paladin / Cleric
    I am not an expert of the Six Thinking Hats, but I cannot readily see where instinct and moral thinking fit in the six thinking hat paradigm. Paladins use combat instinct, or a form of non thinking, or you could say a trained decision pattern. Paladins also pre-think moral decision to give them the speed when they are on scene.
    Six Thinking Hats
    Technique
    ğŸ”µ Big Picture
    âšª Facts
    ğŸ”´ Feelings
    âš« Negative
    ğŸŸ¡ Positive
    ğŸŸ¢ New Ideas
     {"id":"202401011812","parentid":"202212090038","parentname":"Adventurers' Hall","icon":"ğŸ“","title":"Six Thinking Hats","subtitle":"Technique","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2013/07/13/10/41/hat-157581_640.png","music":"","author":"Sasha","description":"","card-text":""}

    Happy New Year! A year has passed since our last NYR setting. Should it renew for another year? Do you have any resolutions?
    As of now only Arcacia completed the logging! StarTree has marked Monthly Backup, Failure Analysis, and Self-Evaluation as completed. Promotion is also done. Book listing is done. I think for Whale/Self Evaluation, we don't really need to show it on a New Year's Resolution because at least I don't use it. I think the Quest Board it doing a good job tracking if it is not done for a month. Same with failure analysis. StarTree please make a blank section for 2024. I think anyone finding it useful can still log progress there, and the link to it will be kept at the quest board. This is not exactly about New Year Resolution, but may I appeal to the entire guild to help work on Arcacian Quest? Specifically, help discuss and change node cards into AQ cards. Do you want to set a goal of how many cards to make within a year? I don't think New Year Resolution works well with a design process where things are rapidly changing. But you could identify metrics and log them at the beginning of each month as a type of diagnostic. I think such information should be at the AQ node, not the New Year Resolution node. You could just JQuery the stats card from the New Year Resolution node. I see. In that case I am interested in showing a Cardinal Quest stats card if someone can format it. I think you could just start with the current layout and add text to the card. I don't think we need to show Cardinal Quest stats on NYR because that cannot be understood by a general visitor. I think it is better if the content there is also interesting to them. I want each member has autonomy in deciding what they want to show there. I don't want that section to be just about promoting the guild. But the NYR link is the first thing on the quest board. The quest board is mostly for us. Maybe it shouldn't. It needs to be for us first, because we are the one doing the quests. It needs to be convenient to us first and foremost. If there needs to be a showcase node then we could just add one. Couldn't it do both? Both convenient to us and is explanatory to a new visitor? I think if you want a showcase node, you may also link to it at the Quest Board. But it is ugly if there are too many links at the Quest Board. The rule was each person / Chapter Master should only have one link. That was why we made that one link collapsible (which opens to more links). I suppose I am proposing that the NYR node be just a link in @Wish. And the top link is changed to Arcacian Quest. I am also making that suggestion because NYR just has a pretty bad reputation of being something that doesn't really work. Where as Arcacian Quest you can't "fail". If I don't define, "what we must complete within this year", then it can't fail. People are going to click on it and just see progress made by everyone: designing layout, drawing, discussing gameplay, philosophy, playtesting, etc. I am not against that idea, but the way it works now is that when Arcacian Quest is Rank S, it would already be listed first. But that is tedious when you work on AQ you also need to update the content for the Quest board. To me it is strange when the same quest shows up in every chapter like how Law Game happened. If it is popular, it should just be a common quest pinned at the top. I agree that it can be pinned at the top, but that doesn't get rid of logging in each chapter for the checkmark, like what we did for Law Game. Since NYR is currently blank for 2024, I would just keep it at @Wish. StarTree please replace the node on top to Arcacian Quest. Done! Thank you. 2023 New Year's Resolution has concluded! @Wish is now ranked B1.
    Progress!
    {"type":"chat","id":"202401011912","parentid":"202301011001","parentname":"NYR","icon":"ğŸŠ","title":"New Year's Resolutions","prev":"202301010947","author":"LRRH","location":"Magic Bakery"}

    I think we need a discussion, perhaps a daily discussion to set the direction so that we know what to complete or explore before the next discussion.
    â˜€ï¸ Daily Agenda
    Sasha: I want to add some structure to the discussion so people don't just bring up questions or not know when to discuss a topic. My plan is that if there is an idea or topic you want to discuss, please first log it at the Items to Discuss section. Then, during the first part of this "daily" discussion, I will roughly prioritize the very long list, and pick one topic that StarTree (or anyone) could work on at night, and start one topic that needs discussion the most. After that the discussion would be open to any topic. The main thing I want to make sure is that StarTree has a clear goal on what to do every night. That will give us time to review the next day. Now first the default assignment.
    So far we have two good hero cards and one good place card. In comparison, we have subpar Quest cards and no "Gem" card at all. Right now what I want to see the most is an updated Quest card or the design of a Gem card to the same art quality. StarTree, tonight please update the quest card so we can check how it shows with a hero, place or item card. Then if there is time left, design the gem card. You may assume that the Gem cards represent items or supplies, that can ALSO be upgraded, but there are two types: Treasures are not discarded after use. Supplies are discarded after use (along with any rank card that the player used to grind up the supply). StarTree added a nightly design queue!
    Now I choose a topic that seems the most pressing. I am not prioritizing the card ideas section at the moment, but StarTree may use content from that section to make cards.
    ğŸ”® Topic: Design Guidelines
    ğŸ”®Sasha: These topics seems short but we need to confirm them for the cards to be designed.
    1: Standardization vs Customization This is a topic about the card layout. What part of the design need to be standardized, which part can vary among cards of different type, or cards of the same type?
    2: Appetizing cards Red made a note that a Rank A card needs to be appetizing.
    1ï¸âƒ£Standardization: I think for overall color harmony, all heroes, places, and item cards (which are physical things) should have the brown/tan pudding color.. Common quest cards (event cards) should be grey, to distinguish them from physical things, because quest cards may also have graphics showing heroes, places or items. So the overall background color is used to tell them apart, along with the big rank letter. The ribbon of a quest card can be colorful because once a quest is done, that part is shown along a hero card like a band or honor. The honor ribbon should be stunning, especially for important or higher level quests. The ribbon will have icon(s) of any skill a hero would gain from the quest, and possibly a title they gain. For example, Spring seasonal quests could have pink ribbons. On Things cards, the upper right corner is reserved for the cost of the card. The reason is once the player obtained those cards, they don't need to see the cost again, so if they stack them in their hand, that part may remain hidden behind other cards. Another reason is that quest card could get "Complicated". A complication card is also a quest card, with its own rank letter, but when it is drawn, it is meant to be placed to the right of the quest card that it complicates. The complication adds to the difficulty by adding more cost icons. It seems complicated. In Splendor, the "quest cards" are laid out in a grid. There is no space to just add a card next to an existing card. What is going on in this gameplay? When a player decides to quest, they move the quest card from the grid to an area before them, where they layout the heroes send for the quest, There is a lot of movement of cards. In Splendor you could just tell others that you are picking that card, and since others can quite easily see what gems you have, you can just point to your gems to show you have enough. Then you take the card. The only necessary movement is taking the card. I don't think it is a big deal to move more. It is just more theatrical so other players can visually see heroes in action. I know I am not contributing but I would just like to say that this seem important and interesting, but I have a hard time visualizing what we are discussing. ğŸ˜… My concern is that the design would take too much space to play. Splendor already takes considerable space. Now you need another staging area, possibly in front of every player. Then they will be quite far from the center of the table to read the quest cards. But it would be fine if each player is not a guild master but just a hero. When they try to do a quest, they just show their relevant hand. Then they take the quest card back into their hand and they may rearrange them however they want. The only thing left shown on the table are the remaining quests. Possibly you don't even need to show item or hero cards, the player may just draw them and have them. They are rewards from the quests. Doing the quest already has a cost, you don't have to charge the player twice. I think Zoey's gameplay is simpler and faster. And does not subtract from theme. I think I can picture Zoey's idea, but what happens when a player draws a second hero from the treasure deck? Either: 1) The players choose which hero they want to be at the beginning, and the treasure deck does not have any hero. 2) A player may have more than one hero in their hand, and they may play more than one hero for a quest per same rule as Sasha's idea. 3) If a player doesn't want another hero, or any card in their hand, they could just leave it on the center of the table for others. Why would a player not want a second hero? Is there a max limit? There is no rule, it is just up to the player. XD In that game mode I think it is better to limit each player to be playing one hero at a time until they decide to switch, or when their hero is KO'ed. So the public heroes are the collective reserve/hitpoints for the team. I like the idea that you could just start with yourself and play yourself. Hopefully throughout the entire session. ğŸ˜– Would there still be building cards? If there are building cards, they would just be shared among the players once they are revealed. They don't go into another player's hand. They remain on the table, then as the game progress, the place cards together show what the town has available for the heroes. I think it would be cute if the building cards can tile into a town map. Although this is possibly not necessary. If you leave the town cards on the table, I think it might be better if the players draw a quest card into their hand instead of laying them out for all to see. Then the things on the table correspond to what the town has. I think if the color / design of the place cards and quest cards are different enough, there is no problem showing both on the table. But more importantly, I think all players need to know what quests there are first, then second they look at which building can help do those quests. The players need to see both. In your design, the players will not know what they will get after completing a quest. Isn't that just normal to dungeon crawl? XD I am not quite ready to let go of the shopping aspect. But isn't that just grinding? You are saying that the player will see an item that they can't immediately get, the item has a price tag, so the player needs to do quest to get the required icons to get the item, so that they can use the item to do more quest. I am just removing one step so that items are rare (since they come from completing quests), but the player still needs to see which icons each quest needs and figure out in what order or which hero do which quest so they are not wasting turns. I don't have a problem with seeing some items or heroes being available for recruitment. I think the recruitment part could be a meaningful part of the game. That is the only time in the game where the player needs to know what a hero wants instead of just using them like pawns. How do you tell which heroes on the table are recruited or not? If it is recruited then it is in your hand. Otherwise you need to fulfill their wish first. So maybe if your hero is KO'ed, they go to the center of the table and you as the player need to pay their cost to revive them (your original hero). I suppose that is fine. This seems exactly the same as my design except the player may choose their starting hero, and buildings are shared by default. But otherwise, you still have quest cards, and potentially items, heroes, and building cards in the middle of the table. What exactly do you do when you decide to "do a quest"? Where are you moving your cards or what card are you moving? As you play, you arrange your cards in your hand to get them ready to show other players. Then when it is your turn, you show that hand and claim the quest card into your hand, along with any bonus loot from the quest. Then, the turn of the next player starts, and you get to arrange your cards for the next quest. A player doesn't need to keep the cards in their hand, they may just lay the cards in front of them if space allows. But the game is designed so that the players may play from their hands. If the game does not require a player to have some cards in front of them, then there would probably be space to do what Sasha wants: To take the quest card in front of the player, then assign the heroes for doing the quest, then lay a complication card, and the players send more heroes to complete the quest. In Splendor I think you have to lay out your mine cards for other competing players to confirm that you did not cheat, and for them to strategize. But this is cooperative. Okay. What I am getting is that there is nothing wrong in this stage 1 design, everything that Zoey has said could be done with the same components by adjusting the rules. Therefore that is a stage 3 topic. How much space is required to play the game is a stage 1 question, I think. Splendor only has twelve cards in the middle. That is about one square foot. There is plenty of space for both quest cards and "shop items". The way I imagine it, in Zoey's design there are no shop items. Maybe there is one row of quest cards, and one row of build cards. In your design, there is that square in the middle, then in addition there are guild halls that each player keep near them, since guild hall bonuses are not shared among the players. Zoey's design does not need that guild hall area, and possibly only 2/3 of the center space. That gives much more space to "stage" the current quest. Okay. Anyway this is a stage 3 question. It is an important question for the final game, for what we choose to present, but not important in terms of what the components need so StarTree can design the layout. I am trying to confirm that: 1) when the player decides to do a quest, it is not entirely deterministic that they will succeed; and 2) the game handles that variation by making the player reveal the next quest card, which could be a complication card. 3) For the art/layout design, the complication card is meant to show on the right side of a quest card, and it has possibly a ribbon on both left and right. 4) If the team succeeds, they take both cards so potentially two things can rank up from the same quest. 5) If the team fails, they put the quest card back with the complication card still showing on top or on the side so the player can see the updated minimum requirement to do the quest. So my question to Zoey is, suppose your design is the main design, do you have a problem if there is an add-on with complication cards meant to be arranged to the right of the quest card? My guess is that you don't because your design doesn't use that space, so there is no conflict. Then I can give the go to StarTree to anticipate designing a status effect card on the right that could be applied to quests. I think that is fine. Roger! I am looking forward to seeing what it looks like. ğŸ˜Š StarTree please add a section describing what part of the layout is standardized which part is variable.
    Card Background: Cards of things have a pudding theme background. Quest cards have a grey background. Left Ribbon: Quest cards have a left ribbon with a rank letter. It is designed to be placed behind a thing card, showing the rank of the thing. The color of the left ribbon is not standardized, but may have a color code for seasonal quests of the same season. A quest card may also have a right ribbon. The icons on the right ribbon corresponds to the effects on the quest, most commonly adding to the overall cost needed to complete the quest. Is the right ribbon color standardized? I think it should be standard. Roger!
    2ï¸âƒ£Appetizing: @LRRH said Rank A needs to be appetizing. Please explain. When you design a card, you should aim for making it something a player would want to eat when they see it. A good card let the viewer imagine interesting possibilities to do with the card. StarTree please add a section on visual appeal with this rubric. Is the Magic Bakery card considered Rank A? Yes What about Zoey and Lucia cards? All three are Rank A. Wee~~! I think that is enough for discussion.

    StarTree: StarTree goes Wee~~!
    Uploaded updated Zoey and Lucia cards. Upgrading quest cards and experimenting....

    This is a routine monthly status update for Cardinal Quest.
    ğŸ“¯StarTree: There are 4 open quests, 214 quest hours, 51 side quests, 0 prep quests, and 72 unresolved failures remaining! Good to update. Done! Now on to TPK record for Failure Analysis.
    2307 Eastern Sea Broken Mast
    ğŸ©StarTree: For the Eastern Sea quest, a different team installed a wrongly designed part to the mast. When it was our turn to work on the mast, the mast crashed when it rotated, even when it could rotate the day before. Our preventative measure for next time is to test the rotation slowly if it is our first time doing it in our shift!
    There was one more countermeasure: that we need to be better trained to stop the rotation if anything seems strange. Copy!
    Tanya thanks all for questing. @Cardinal is now Rank B2.

     {"id":"202401021825","parentid":"202208172107","parentname":"Music Room","icon":"ğŸ¼","title":"Chord Progression","subtitle":"Study","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2016/02/29/23/15/sheet-music-1229481_1280.jpg","music":"","author":"P4","description":"","card-text":""}
    ğŸ””
    The law game continues. Natalie: Please be aware that the content may not be appropriate for children, and that we play this game from a philosophical standpoint. The answers are not meant to be representative of all jurisdictions.
    [258] Borrowed Weapon
    ğŸ“¯Natalie: [258] Ann and Bob plan to burglarize a cheese factory at night. She gave Bob a gun just in case to threaten any employee. But during the act, a guard discovers Bob and Bob uses the gun to fire at the guard. If the guard is hit and killed, would Ann be liable to the felony murder if Ann genuinely did not expect Bob to fire the gun?
    Ann is liable for conspiracy, burglary, and felony murder. Yes she is liable. A gun is a deadly weapon, and burglary is a case where the property may use deadly force, so Ann should be liable for felony murder because she should know burglary is inherently violent. Correct! Since burglary is a dangerous felony and Bob is an accomplice, Ann would also be liable for the felony murder.
    @Paladin is now Rank B2. This is the first game in 2024!
    {"type":"chat","id":"202401021935","parentid":"202301011739","parentname":"Law Game","icon":"âš–ï¸","title":"Law Game 100","prev":"202312292103","author":"Natalie","location":"Paladin Hall"}
    â­
    A section with Design Review Slides are added. If there is no change in course StarTree will make some gem cards!
    It looks cute and professional at the same time. I think we need more time for people to review and comment on the layout and art choices. So I will first do an agenda section.
    ğŸ”® TPK Forecast
    Sasha: The first item on the agenda is checking the todo list, sort the new topics and start with any item that could lead to a TPK.
    As of now there is nothing in the TPK forecast section (Since I have just added that section 10 seconds ago). But if you can think of something that could lead to TPK, please directly put it there. Right now the sections are more organized, so when you add a topic please add directly to the section. So now I move onto the next section.
    ğŸ€ Minimum Playtest
    ğŸ“¯Sasha: This section is about what is the minimum components we need for a playtest. So, forget about a year-long game. Let's start with a single player and one quest card. Can the player complete the quest? Would it be fun? Would it be educational?
    The quest card of Mira Mira Grand Reopening is not very high in educational content. But let's focus on the gameplay first. Say the player sits down and draw just one quest card, and the quest card is the Grand Reopening card. The player sees the cost and the reward of completing the quest. What does the player need to do? What does the player need to decide? Are those decisions fun? Sasha returns to her DPS nature. Attacking her own design. For good. XD Are we playing as Zoey being the hero that the player already has? If so, I think the quest card means I still need to get a card with a shield, a card with a heart, and a card with a clover. If this was Splendor, you would spend one turn to get three different gems, then you may complete the quest in the next turn. In our current design, how do you "draw three different resources"? In the design review slides I don't see the six decks of "gem" cards. Let's say the Town Deck only has 6 cards: the 6 basic cards. At the start of the game, 5 of 6 cards are already revealed on the Town Row. What are the player actions? Can they directly draw the unrevealed card from the deck? What actions would be fun to you as a player? I want the option to draw from the deck. This is an interesting move when you know the unrevealed card has what you need based on deduction. It would make sense to do so if you need just one card, then the player would save one turn by using deduction. Okay. Let's say the player may choose to take one revealed card if they can pay for it (basic cards have no cost other than the turn they spent doing it), or they may draw the top card from the Town Deck. Who else? What move would be fun? If there is a discard pile, I want my character to have an ability to just take from discard. Consider that done one way or another. It will probably be a skill, but not a unique skill. Your hero card could just start with that skill icon. For this quest, the quest reward should not have the ribbon and the scissors, those items should be the cost. The player is supposed to get a ribbon and a scissors for the ceremony. Instead of the four basic cost icons, the costs should be the quest items Ribbon and Scissors. In the Town Deck, then you need to have some cards with Ribbons and Scissors. I thought we wanted the cards to be interchangeable, if you make a quest that requires a scissors card, then when you add the quest you also need to make sure that you also add a scissors card. According to the Vision Survey. But that is a Rank B goal. Would you rather have a game with interchangeable cards but not fun, but a fun deck with interchangeable event modules? An S-Ranked Cake is a wild card. There is no missing key item as long as you reach your baking skill to Rank S. And that is an educational lesson. I think for the game to be fun for Red it must have at least one card with pastry. Evelyn gets it. StarTree please add "Fun to Play" as Rank A design goal to Vision Survey. Done! Suppose the quest cost is a ribbon and a scissors, and suppose you don't want there to be just one specific card with ribbon and another card with scissors in the whole deck, maybe one of the basic cards is "art supplies", which has ribbons and scissors and paint and other crafting tools. The other five basic cards can be designed similarly. Maybe one with food items, and one with stationeries. StarTree when you make the six basic cards please make them like that. Then we can see what happens. On those cards they should still show the main type icon because we still need them for general costs at higher rank quests. Roger! Is this fun: When a quest card needs an item that is on a basic card, it may not refer to the basic type. But an observant player could spot and remember which card has the item. I think that can be fun, like spot-it. But are you going to have copies of basic cards? Or are they all slightly different like Spot-in? I want each card to be unique, but there could be multiple basic shield card but with different sub items. The minimum gameplay could have 5 cards: The hero card with a horn, the quest card with costs: horn, ribbon, and scissors, and three item cards: one art supplies card with scissors and ribbon and others, one food items card with produces, and one Rank S cake card with the explanation that it is a wildcard card for one cost item. The game starts by revealing only two out of three Town cards. Then, if you tell the player to finish the quest by taking just one card, then there is always just one correct answer. I think that makes a good tutorial to demonstrate how to play. StarTree please prioritizes these three cards. Roger! Is this fun so far? Any more ideas? I think this may work as a narrated tutorial but if you just show it as a puzzle and ask the player to solve it, it might be too challenging for some. But as long as the player is guided, I think it would be fun. To avoid the 202301071252|Abilene Paradox, please check if this is fun to you, not to a hypothetical player. What would make it fun for you? I think if one of the two revealed cards is art supplies, although it is simple I would make the connection to complete the quest. But if the art supplies card is not yet revealed, I think I would be confused and pick the cake card because I may not make a connection that the unknown card is art supplies with both quest items. But the food items card has more than one object, so you know a card can be a category with multiple objects. I am not confident that if you show that puzzle to me out of the blue, I would draw the correct (the unrevealed) card. ğŸ˜– But even if you get it wrong, would it be fun when you see the answer? To me such a puzzle would be fair game even if you get it wrong the first try. I think it would make more sense to me if the back of the art supplies card says "Art Supplies", then I would be more likely to get that card even when I don't know for sure that it has a ribbon and scissors. I am thinking very hard whether the back of the card can say "art supplies", but my ideas are leaning heavily toward a no. And we are not yet designing the back of the card. I don't think you need to put a lot of weight on my comment because as long as the tutorial is narrated I think the player would understand. If it is narrated, the example won't be random. Then perhaps the very first example should be just three cards, hero, quest, and art supplies. The art supplies card is already revealed. The narration says on the player's turn the player sees that she already has a horn, and the art supplies card has the ribbon and scissors. So she gets that card to complete the quest. Can the player take a card and immediately use it to complete a quest? I think that should be a Yes because it is faster and more exciting if the player is betting on the deck card and got it. I think after Black's first example, Tanya's example would be less confusing because the player would already know that the deck has an art supplies card with a ribbon and a scissors. I don't think we really need to present Tanya's puzzle as part of a tutorial because it could be something fun the player discovers while playing: This is the last turn to complete a quest, and what you need is not revealed. Do you just take a revealed but useless card, or do you draw from the deck? I think it should be included in the tutorial because that is a lesson on hope: It is not over until it is over. Deep. Maybe one of the revealed cards should be a hint about sometimes it is a good idea to dive into the unknown. Tutorial cards should have as few words as possible. All cards should have as few words as possible. Unless the words make the game fun. I think it is too preachy if you spell it out for the player. I think it is fine if you as the designer say you designed the game that was to implicitly teach hope. But if you explicitly tell the player what they are supposed to learn as part of the game, then it takes away from the fun. I see. Is that official? If there is a rubric ranking the educational value of the game, would the game be marked down for having preachy cards? The cards are supposed to be funny, not preachy. Or preaching humorously. What is the official ranking? I think if the preachy saying is short, it would still be fine since the cards are colorful with cute graphics. Sasha? I think the game should be funny and educational, not preachy. To me preachy means something else that is mostly negative. If a card has text, you want the player to enjoy reading, not feeling repulsed. It is a good discussion. Let's wait for the cards and continue next time.
    @Carrot is now Rank B1.

Please also make mock hero cards without its own ribbon for comparison. For overall layout demo, please continue with your Slide 04 layout, and put on queue to design the NG card. Roger!     In this node, the term "immigration" covers all kinds of entrance into a territory other than entire "in-transit". This includes entering as a tourist, a worker, to live temporarily or permanently.
    ğŸ“ When is a border legit?
    At peace paradigm ranking 3 (Coexistence) or better, a border is legit if it protects the autonomy of people inside the border (the occupiers) without violating the autonomy of people outside the border (the outsiders). In general, this means that the occupiers need to be either good or at least better stewards of the occupied land, and have the requisite population to bank on the occupation.
    A country (with borders) becomes a violator in these examples:
    Laying ecological waste
    The country is laying ecological waste to its territory. By failing to sustain their part of the world for future generation, the country has no rights to exclude better stewards from taking control and heal the land. (International law based on Stewardism principles)
    Having a negative NMR
    The country has a negative net migration rate (NMR-, meaning more people are trying to move out than to move in) due to unfavorable politics and amenities maintained by the country's government. The change in NMR shall be matched with a change in the country's territory to allow the migrants the option of independence or to assign their share to a country of their choice. (International law based on Hospitality principles)
    Seizing a natural wonder
    The country erected a border around a natural wonder and prevents other well-meaning visitors and researchers. (It is a violation in Stewardism to not share natural wonders.)
    Violating freedom of association
    The country erected a border preventing a family from inviting someone of their choice to live with. (Violation on Autonomy in Stewardism: You may appoint your own helpers and household members)
    A border is legit when it doesn't violate the principles, for example:
    Stewardism
    A person has a right to establish a personal border to take good care of the land without violating others' right to access natural wonder, or to prevent others from having their fair share of autonomous territory. Within this principle, people may combine their shares and claim a larger territory. A typical stewardism world map does not have large territory area such as a border between the US and Mexico. Instead, it would have borders around individual autonomous city states where the citizens of a city had opted in to the city's constitutional way of life, thus having a consensus on the city's own citizen/immigration policy. The rest of the connective land is a common zone, where people many normally travel of camp responsibly without any visa. In this view (which may not be a final verdict covering all considerations), the US-Mexico border would be considered illegitimate in Stewardism. An ecologically responsible employer, such as a farmer, is considered a steward of the land. The size of the farm it is allowed to take care of is based on the number of people wanting to get produce from their farming. That interdependence justifies the farmer their autonomy over the land (which a single person normally can't have so much land). That autonomy then allows the farmer to invite helpers from anywhere. They may summon seasonal farmers from another world if they want, especially if they also provide housing within their autonomous land.
    ğŸ“ When is it okay to use voting to establish a border?
    In Stewardism, voting is not a legal decision method when it is used to rule over (violate) individual autonomy. The autonomy of an employer trying to hire a seasonal worker, and the worker accepting the hiring shall not be violated. You can't use voting to forbid them from working together.
    A situation where voting would be relevant is when the employer has opted into a city state that either forbids, or has no law regarding whether it is okay to hire outsiders. Then the city state has four normal choices:
    Survey for Consensus
    Conduct a survey and have discussion/debates to see if there is a consensus. If so, the constitution of the city state can be updated with no conflict.
    Sub division
    If the occupants have divided visions, begin a process of internal division as needed. The division could be geographical (those who support the policy start moving to the left side of the river) or subscriptional (those who support the policy shall opt out of benefit A, which was formerly applied to all occupants in the city state)
    Relocation within an alliance
    Collaborate with fellow city states sharing a similar issue, and designate which city state to be the city of which updated constitution. In this case, a form of voting can be used legally to decide which view takes which side of the city.
    Building new city states
    Start building another city state with an updated constitution so that people sharing that principle may live together without coming into conflict with those who oppose. A form of voting may be used to decide which view keeps the original city. Under Hospitalian principle, once the population divides and part of it move to a new city, the original city state need to find new comers to fill its vacancy, or it could lose its legitimacy of keeping its territory. If a city state is confident that plenty of people would move in if it updates its constitution, then it would normally pick (c) to facilitate political relocation among city states within the alliance instead of asking minority dissenters to "go build your own city".
    ğŸ“ What can you do if you live in a country with an illegitimate border policy?
    You could discuss and explain the principles to deconstruct biases and misconceptions. The current law (in your country, or in terms of international law) is not necessarily correct. There is evidence that the current law is incorrect. So look into the future to identify what the law should be and build a positive culture supporting people correcting the laws.
    {"id":"202401031108","parentid":"202207161423","parentname":"Philosophies","icon":"ğŸ’¼","title":"Immigration","subtitle":"Policy","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2016/11/04/23/23/luggage-1799224_1280.jpg","music":"","author":"Black","description":"","card-text":""}
    â­
    This continues the design review of Arcacian Quest.
    ğŸ”® TPK Forecast (5)
    Sasha: This time we have five things logged for TPK Forecast. It seems that they are concerns that the game would not be educational.
    How should we start? Should we list how the game is supposed to be educational, or how it is used in training? I think we should start by defining the rank letter of a quest based on its peacemaking value. I think that would be among the first thing a player asks when they see a quest card, "What does this rank letter mean?" My suggestion: A quest that is Rank S should be about spreading peace to a region that is hostile. Rank A is about spreading peace to where it is reluctant. Rank B to where the people are simply ignorant. Rank C to where peaceful people need help. Rank D is where you just train yourself. Wow, that's new. What did you intent the rank to mean? I think I just saw it as some kind of progress indicator based on difficulty. Such as a rank D quest requires 1 to 4 skills to complete, Rank C quest requires 1 to 4 D-ranked skills to complete (so 5 to 16 skills). Rank B quest requires 1 to 4 C-ranked skills to complete, etc. I like Tanya's idea. If the rank is relevant to peacemaking then it helps to set the context a lot. But then there is a disconnect between what we normally call an S ranked skill and an S ranked quest. When a skill is rank S it just means the user is good at it an unlikely to fail. So, what about the skills when the rank card is attached to a skill? I don't see a difference. After completing a Rank S quest, it means the hero has experience using their skill to make peace in a hostile situation. Then their peacemaking skill is Rank S. Okay. Any objection to Tanya's suggestion? Just to be clear, in that scale, would catching a theft a rank S quest, but stopping a meteor from hitting earth a rank A quest? If a meteor is about to hit it is possible for crime to just shoot up. You could face many people hostile to your solution unless everyone just agree on what to do. Same with any disaster situations. Tanya's concept is new to me, I think the rank should be about accrediting the hero's skills, if the game is about training peacemakers, I suppose having a rank pertaining to their peacemaking ability is fitting. But wouldn't that make it quite easy to get rank S skill? If you have combat skill, you are using it against someone hostile to peace. You don't necessary spread peace to a suspect when you arrest them. They simply become unable to violate. To spread peace means you need to reach their intention. Your combat skill is just part of the process. So you mean when a meteor is coming, S-ranked peacemaking means reaching to people who would have wants to do crimes during the chaos to choose to cooperate instead. Exactly. That should be harder than just catching one theft and convince them not to steal any more. I agree with Tanya's suggestion. The thing that should have this explanation is the game manual, which would be a Stage 3 task. For now I think we need a new Stage 1 section listing how the game trains peacemaking. StarTree. Done! I think in the game, we could use basic ğŸ“ cards to briefly show game-related rules, definitions, and hints. Some of them could be just straight principle. I have two objections about that: 1) I think we don't want many ğŸ“ cards, otherwise the deck will be thick and tedious. 2) I think we don't want to be preachy and should avoid text on the actual card. StarTree could you add Black's suggestion but with a yellow box? Tanya's should have a green box because I think we are adopting that idea. But it could work for someone using it as a deck of flash cards. The gameplay doesn't care about the text as long as it is a ğŸ“. The game could have 1000s of ğŸ“ cards, but for a given game, the game deck only has a few of them. If the player may print their own cards I think it is okay to let the player choose which cards they want to print. StarTree please consider Black's idea when making the basic knowledge card. It seems that that card does not need many icons, just an actual piece of definition or principle. Roger! I think this covers two of Tanya's TPK forecasts. Let's do the ones from Vivi and Black next.
    ğŸ“¯Sasha: Both Vivi and Black said we need a quest corresponding to a real life peacemaking issue. Black suggested that "correcting immigration law" can be a quest.
    Correcting the law on immigration would be a rank S quest because many people do not want the law to change, especially when they are benefited by that policy. StarTree please add two things: your queue to make a correct the law quest card, and "using real life situations" as a training means. Done! I still have a question about the ranking. The original design was that the players are trying to complete all quests. I assumed that the final scoring would be about the quests that remain, and the rank correspond to deduction points. Is this true? Or how is the game scored. I think that can still be true. Some quest cards would have a penalty written on them that if they are not completed, the players need to discard cards. So you do the final count after running all the penalties, and count also the rank cards in discard. I think the way scoring is done is part of the training, that the goal of a peacemaker is about that final score. Added! Right now we only have one TPK Forecast remaining. We will do it next time. And I think Vivi can lead the Art Design Review since she is closer to StarTree. I am also renaming "stages" into "tracks" because the two are going in parallel.
    @Dungeon is now Rank B3.

    1/3 Slide 01: Mini Tutorial Review I am skipping the gameplay details. But I think the Art Supplies card should be a â¤ï¸ card and the Vegetables card should be ğŸ€.
    1/3 Slide 02: I prefer choice B because it has more space at the bottom where the cost of the card could be.
    1/3 Slide 03: The Art Supplies and Vegetables cards look good, but the two wildcard cards are sub-par. SchrÃ¶dinger's Case seems out of place. Having item names on the side seem excessive. They make the card slightly too noisy. For the stacking, I think the cards should be stackable vertically like MTG cards. The top of a town card should show the item name if it is a town card, followed by its abilities. The top of a quest card should have the rank letter and its abilities when completed. I find it easier to pick up vertically stacked cards than to pick up horizontally stacked cards. If the cards are stacked horizontally, you can stand them up by using a standee base. What if quest cards are longer? Then setup would be easier because you can easily separate all quest cards from a pile or a mixed deck. StarTree please try. Roger!

    StarTree is updating the card layouts!
    Made a new layout for supply card. Making template for a longer (tarot) card format. The extra length, which has the rank ribbon, is planned to be 0.5" making the overall card dimensions 4"x2.5" for quest cards. Made new Hero layout. Remaking Grand Reopening quest card. Print testing. If the tarot size is 4x2.5, one 4x6 photo paper can only print one card. Now testing 3.75x2.5. I think in the end we won't be printing on 4x6 paper. We shouldn't use what is convenient during prototype to decide the end result. Also making 4x2.5 for review. I think 4" is better. And make the top just "Stunning", just an adjective. Add the horizontal bar also for supply card, and add the top title text for hero. The top banner needs to be opaque, and make it blue for better comparison. Done! Now making a knowledge card. How are these cards? Is the QR code readable by a phone? Print testing. This is the smallest incremental size for it to be readable. 0.5 x 0.5. That card is boring and having the QR code breaks immersion. If you want a QR code it should just be in the manual. I think the middle of the card could be a town scene. There is no stock image! I think we can improve it later. Looking up AI images for prototype, remaking cards with visual aid scenes. Could you put the QR code on the right? Most phone have the camera on the right. Roger! For the knowledge card I like E the most. Having the QR code on the left looks more normal to me because it resembles a block of drop cap character. ğŸ˜– And I like the Vegetables card with a circle background instead of oval. ğŸ˜– Made some changes. I think D looks good. ğŸ¤— I am not a big fan of the tarot sized card. I think the result is too tall and it looks ridiculous. I think you can't properly tell how the card feels in your hands when you play it. Imagine you are holding a dozen cards. When a quest is revealed, you need to quickly see what cards you have in hand. So the cards need to be designed so they can be held like a fan, or at least have enough information on the edge for the player to quickly scan through them in hand. I agree that the game should play fast, but not like Uno fast. There could be a more exciting semi-competitive mode where someone reveals a quest and whoever places the questing team first gets the quest. What? XD I think we should prioritize the cooperative mode where the players can see each other's cards. Can the cards have both a top and left ribbon? Roger! @Treasure is now Rank B2.

    For discussion points logging.
    â¤ï¸ Art Design
    â­5 StarTree: Making the side ribbons higher contrast for legibility.
    I think the card without the side border looks better, but having the border is also good, and the game probably plays better with the border. I think we should just keep two formats: One for displaying on the website and one for playing from hand. And Zoey's profile is now updated with the Arcacian Quest card. Nice! If there is nothing pressing about the art Design, I want to discuss rubrics in the TPK section.
    @Mira is now Rank A2.
    ğŸ“¯ Rubrics
    Sasha: According to Tanya, we need a rubric for the fun factor and the educational factor. What is S rank fun? Or perhaps we should start with C rank?
    Rank S fun would be like a show you are following and look forward to play the next game or when you know a new expansion is coming out, you would want to replay the old ones. XD I can totally relate. Great description! Rank C would be it being enjoyable at least the first time playing it. We have a set numerical method of determining the ranks. Shouldn't Rank C Fun simply mean at least 50% of the people find the game fun to play? Then almost all games will be Rank F. XD Or not even. XD But if we use that we could still discuss the ranking among a subset of the population. Exactly. But there are still two dimensions: The percentage of people who find it "fun", and *how much* "fun" they find. You may call my level of fun "acceptable" or "enjoyable" or "worth playing at least once." I don't have a problem calling that level of fun "Rank C". If this is Amazon, you could see both the star rating and the number/percentage of people who gave that many stars. In terms of this step, I am less worried about "what Rank S means" or "how do we measure it", but "let's have a better scale describing what we are trying to achieve." So I am asking, "what would 5-star fun mean to you?" Then I call my Rank S/5-Star "Addictive". I don't think we should aim for that... ğŸ˜– Healthily Addictive. Okay ğŸ¤— I changed to stars to avoid confusion. Zero or one star (whatever lowest), would be unplayable. Such as when the player can't figure out how to play despite them wanting to play and like the game. In Ledia's rating the game could be "Rank S in Unreplayability" XD Convenient isn't it? Last time we said that a Rank S quest means spreading peace to hostile entities. According to Ledia what would be a Rank S Quest? That ranking is for a skill. If you say successful completion of that quest means the team can reliably spread peace to hostiles, then you can accredit the team Rank S in such peacemaking. When you say a quest is "rank S', it means that completing it can get you certified as Rank S in some skills. I see. I think there is no problem keeping that ranking because a "high ranking" peacemaker can make peace with hostile entities. It is implied that they may also make peace or help cooperative entities. So it is still the same scale. Then why can't we rank fun factor in S-ranking? Once we know what the top ranking means, we could just roughly assume that other ranks follow. I think the star rating is more descriptive and accurate. Is there something else we can do than to show a quest with a letter rank? I think people would confuse a letter rank with a letter grade, "If I finish this quest I can only get a D. Do I get a D no matter how well I do?" Maybe the letter ranking should be a level rating. People don't complain when they complete a Level 1 quest and earn a Level 1 card. What do others think? If the underlying skills are the same, I don't see a problem with using S-ranking as long as the game does not prevent a team of Rank D heroes attempting a Rank S quest. But for the sake of simulation, the lower the hero ranks, the higher chance they should fail. So maybe for each additional rank gap you draw one more complication card. I am starting a terminology section. Any other comments on whether we should change the rank lettering in labeling quests? I am too used to Naruto quest ranking to say no. We gotta refer to quests by letter rank. XD If a bunch of unranked completes a Rank S quest, does one of them become Rank S? Since the only quest card you could give them is a Rank S card. I think yes. But that would be unlikely due to the way the skills are designed. The kind of skill that a Rank S quest requires probably either: 1) Comes from completion of Rank A quests; or 2) Requires Rank A basic skills. If the heroes don't have any Rank A card, I have planned that each rank card is equivalent to four cards one rank below. So if a bunch of unranked want to complete a Rank A skill, they need 4x4x4x4 = 256 basic skill cards. There simply aren't that many cards. XD To reply to Tanya suggestion earlier, we probably don't need to draw more complication cards. I see. Can I make the same argument to keep the S-rank rating for fun factor? It looks better to say we want this game to be Rank S in fun factor than we want it to get a 5-star ratings. "Rank S" sounds more objective whereas a star rating is more about popularity. To me. Let's sit on this topic and come back to it if we still want to talk about it. For now it is unchanged. Rank S fun means healthily addictive. Okay. What about the ranking of educational value? It seems that "educational value" and our quest rank are the same. This game has Rank S in educational value if it can reliably recruit a hostile entity into peacemaking. I interpolated and added two ranks E and F. Okay. It seems that Tanya's TPK forecast item is resolved. Next time we will continue with discussing what we need at the minimum for a play test.
    @Seed is now Rank B2.
    Adding cards as index type. Is there anything I should draw for this game? I think 3B also needs a queue for drawing. The next item on StarTree's queue is to make a quest card corresponding to a real issue, such as "Correcting Immigration Law". StarTree doesn't know what to do! Let's have a session.

    StarTree: StarTree's queue has an item of making a quest card for correcting immigration law. What is expected from StarTree?
    I made a node 202401031108|here on immigration laws. I want to see it as a quest card. This is a layout question. I just want to see where the icons would go and whether we will use number or letter to represent the difficulty of the required skills. I am against numbers because it makes the players count, which will slow down the game. One order of Quest Card coming up! Is StarTree making a tarot card or standard card? Tarot please. Roger! I want to see the same quest card formatted in standard... One of each! Making new ribbon for Tarot template. Downloading Bitter and Merriweather fonts, and Fuzzy Bubbles. Preparing new icons. Making Standard sized layout Print testing of QR code and tweaking Choice A still need a big rank letter in additional to the small one in the corner. I think Choice B looks the best and is probably functional with hand version since a player shouldn't have that many quest cards. I think choice C also looks good if the letter A is not repeated. The small A is now changed to a medal! I think it looks better without the wheeled luggage. Updating the spotlight version. Among the three choices, C is acceptable, but there is no standard card sleeves for that tarot size. You don't need a sleeve for that size. You would insert it into the sleeve of another card. I think it would be annoying having to put a card into another card. But choice A isn't impactful enough. Tweaking the design. Now I say Choice A is the best. I think so too. Wee~~! Is the quest card better than the one at the node? Let's set it as the node image. Done! For the Spotlight version, could you make the rank letters gold color or use stars? The red color is too distracting. Done! Could you change the code so that people can right click and open the image in new tab? Done! Could you add the stars to standard also? Beneath the Rank letter. Done!

    This is a review of topics related to gender laws
    âš–ï¸ Duty to report to parents
    Q: Does a school have a duty to report to the parents about a child's behavior and requests?

    Considerations

    • A Teacher as an Agent If the family is in a captive state, the public school is an agent to the student family. The family has the right to know what happens with their child at school and what is happening at the school in general. The role of a teacher must align with the intent of the family, standing in as the family in their absence. The public school has no rights to form a contract of confidentiality against the host family. This is because the school is an transparent agent acting in the interest of the host family. The student may form such contract only when they are no longer dependents, and become their own principals. A parent shall be allowed to either choose a school based on its policies, or choose what information they want to be reported. The right to information and notification is not limited to the child's behavior, but also on any changes to the rules and conditions of the facility.
    • A Parent as a Resident Sovereignty The parent providing housing to their dependent has a right to know the condition of their dependent returning and enter the house. The dependent only has a right to choose a different hosing family, but does not have a right to secrets kept from their current family unless such level of privacy is part of the housing agreement.
    • A Child as a Dependent The housing family's rights to know ends when the child is not their dependent.

    Arcacian Law

    • Free families form captor government This issue becomes a political issue only because the state is a captor. If the families are free from the captor, the families would be free to choose the school they want based on the school's policies. Therefore in this case Arcacian Law would help families deconstruct captive laws or escape from the captor state.
    • Help families attend desired school In shorter terms, Arcacian law supports policies that allow the families to choose their school.
    • Help dependents get desired hosts For conflicts between a dependent and their hosting family, Arcacian law helps in providing free counselling and helping the dependent find a more compatible host family.
    âš–ï¸ Gender Segregated Facilities and Competitions
    Q: Do students have the right to use facility and join sports in the gender that they identify with?

    Considerations

    • Choice Democracy In choice democracy, the people (principals) have a right to establishment of gender-segregated facilities with rules as defined by them. The government should not have legislative power to veto that principal desire. The government shall only act as an enforcing agent. So there would just be non-gendered facilities and competitions as the default, but the people have a right to make gender-specific facilities and competition. A public school shall budget proportionally its sports and facility funds to accommodates the desires of the student/family body. This means that as long as there is a demand, the public school MUST provide both non-gender specific sports competitions and gender specific sports competitions with the definition of gender enforced according to the principal petitioners (the parents). The public school system has no right to veto the principal right to decide how to spend their share of the budget.
    • See also 202305302137|Sports Membership

    Arcacian Law

    • Help people define facilities and competition Arcacian law simply help people build and define the facilities they want and competitions they want to have. It is okay if people want to have a gender-specific competition as long as no one is preventing gender-non-specific competitions to also be held.
    âš–ï¸ Sex change procedures to minors
    Q: Can a minor (under 18 yo) get sex change procedure? Even with parental consent?

    Considerations

    • Consent I think if the guardian, the minor, and the practitioner are all willing, the law should not prohibit.
    • People Principal Governance In People-Principal government, each family is allowed to write their family law. This initiative overreaches and violates the family's autonomy.
    • Liability If the child, after procedure, regrets or claims that they were in capable of giving consent, the government and other families shall NOT be held liable due to the understanding that at the time of the procedure, there was not evidence that the child made a decision under duress for anyone to safely decide that their intervention would not violate the child's autonomy. Since the third parties cannot be held liable, the third parties also cannot demand to intervene or stop the procedure based on the trying to "do what they think is right." If a third party decides to intervene, the third party becomes liable to the violation. (If the child grows up and say, "I wanted to change my sex but you stopped me. I didn't appreciate it and I still don't." The child may now sue you for damage which you cannot rationally compute and compensate).

    Arcacian Law

    • Help people do what they want for themselves In this case Arcacian Law help people do what they want to themselves.
    Gender Laws
    Law
     {"id":"202401061155","parentid":"202207161423","parentname":"Philosophies","icon":"ğŸ¦¢","title":"Gender Laws","subtitle":"Law","img":"https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2019/02/22/10/26/swan-4013225_1280.jpg","music":"","author":"Black","description":"","card-text":""}
    ğŸ””
    At NextDoor, someone posted a link to three ballot initiatives regarding gender identity. Are they Arcacian? If not, what would be the Arcacian take on those issues?
    ğŸ“¯ Links and Articles
    Black: These are links to the initiatives for this discussion.:
    Ballotpedia Summaries {"cmd":"url","url":"https://news.ballotpedia.org/2023/09/08/protect-kids-california-files-three-initiatives-related-to-gender-and-schools-sports-and-healthcare-for-the-2024-ballot/","desc":"ğŸ”—"} Article on the initiative wording being changed {"cmd":"url","url":"https://www.capradio.org/articles/2024/01/03/group-to-sue-california-ag-over-title-of-ballot-initiative-seeking-to-prohibit-gender-affirming-care-for-trans-youth/","desc":"ğŸ”—"} Do we plan to reply, if so, where? That is to be determined, based on whether we can find a clear solution to the conflict.
    ğŸ“¯ Critical Review of Initiative 1
    ğŸ“¯Black: According to Ballotpedia summary, this initiative would require the school to report to the parents when their children ask the school to treat them as a different gender. Is this Arcacian?
    The word "require" is a red flag. I think Arcacian law is that the school is neither required to nor required not to report. That should just be an agreement between the school and the family when they decide which school to attend. Then does a child have a right to form an agreement with a teacher to keep their pronoun confidential from their family? The school has autonomy on deciding the school policy, and the families have the autonomy of which school to choose. What if the families are living in a captive state where they are currently forced to fund the same public school for at least the next 10 years, and there are no other education options? In that limited situation, would it be more justified if the school reports or not? Is such decision subjected to voting, or would one choice be a violation of someone's autonomy? Even if there is only one school, this could be handled as a waiver. A parent could sign a waiver if they agree not to know what happens to their children at school? In your comment, the default is that the parent has the right to know, and their right to know overrides the child's right to conceal. Why is it this way but not the other way around? As long as the child is a dependent, the parent has the right to know because the child returns to their care at their residence. The parent has the right to know and investigate who or what is returning into their house, which is their optional zone. You can't have a law asking a family to accept something into their care while preventing them from knowing what is entering. Okay. So if the child wants "privacy" the child would need to basically choose a different family. The Arcacian part is that Arcacian Law will help the child to get a more compatible family. Arcacian Law helps families pick a school they want, and helps a child pick a family they want. Then my interpretation is that it should be the law that a) on request, the school has a responsibility to report about the child to their legal guardians; and b) there needs to be a mechanism for a family to select what type of behavior they want a report; and c) the child has no right to prevent a teacher from reporting; and d) the teacher has no right to not report on the chosen topics (because the teacher is an agent). I think I agree. But I want to first see how you would summarize that at the node. Composing. There is another part about the facility. I think the parent has a right to know who goes into which restroom at the facility. Yes. What I am getting is that Initiative 1 would be part of Arcacian Law. It cannot be voted on. It can only pass because it is part of the hosting family's constitutional right to know what is entering their family. Is this correct? There is some non-consequential error or ambiguity in wording, but in general yes. What errors and ambiguity? When a family can choose a school, it is not "the law" that requires a school (public or private) to report. It is the family who may choose whether to attend a school, and the law simply helps enforce that service agreement between the family and their chosen school. A simple change in wording to "Require public schools" could fix that. The second is what Evelyn said. It is not clear if the school would report when someone else's child will start using a certain restroom. If Bob asks to be treated as female and be allowed to use female facilities, the school has a duty to inform ALL parents that this has happened, not just Bob's parent. The authorization that the school shall get is not just from Bob's parent, but from all affected parents. The summary used a singular "parent". The notice does not need to point out that it was Bob who requested, but ALL parents need to know the happening. It goes back to the principal's right to know all about the agent. Okay. Let's check the next one.
    ğŸ“¯ Critical Review of Initiative 2
    ğŸ“¯Black: This one is about whether students have the right to use facility and join sports that they identify with.
    I think we talked about this before. In choice democracy, the people (principals) have a right to establish gender-segregated facilities with rules as defined by them. The government should not have legislative power to veto that principal desire. The government shall only act as an enforcing agent. So there would just be non-gendered facilities and competition as the default, but the people have a right to make gender-specific facilities and competition. StarTree finds this 202305302137|node on sports membership! Then from the summary, the initiative again shall pass without voting. For the common zone, no voting required. On to the last one.
    ğŸ“¯ Critical Review of Initiative 3
    ğŸ“¯Black: This is about prohibiting prescription of hormonal medical procedures to minor. It seems that this initiative is not about consent.
    I think if the guardian, the minor, and the practitioner are all willing, the law should not prohibit. In People-Principal government, each family is allowed to write their family law. This initiative overreaches and violates the family's autonomy. What if the counter argument is that such procedure is child endangerment, qualifying for extraction? But there is no evidence of a victim if the choice is voluntary. You can't extract people exercising their autonomy. That is just invasion of their autonomy.
    Summary
    Black: Okay. In summary, Initiative 1 and 2 are okay. But 3 is not.
    Agreed. It seems that this subject doesn't need many concept to judge. So far we have this: Autonomy, Zoning, Principal/Agent relation, Dependents laws, Choice Democracy, and maybe Consent. Six concepts. Are we now talking about AQ? I think a quest to figure out what is correct would be Rank D. That is just self-training. If you report your findings to someone who is willing to listen, then it would be Rank C. I think we should report and point out that the third initiative is a violation. I suppose if we merely report, but does not aim to debate or change their opinion, then the quest rank remains D. Replied. Your reply has additional content that should be copied back to the node. Will do. I think we need a list of what quests are what rank for consistency. That could be part of Game Terms. Done!
    @Carrot is now Rank S2.
    Wee~~!
    {"type":"chat","id":"202401061204","parentid":"202401061155","parentname":"Gender Laws","icon":"âš–ï¸","title":"Gender Laws","prev":"","author":"Black","location":"Freedom Plaza"}

    This is StarTree working on her queue!
    â¤ï¸ NG Card
    StarTree: The NG card is a quest card mixed in the quest deck. When the questing players are ready to finish a quest, a card is drawn from the quest deck. If it is an NG card, the questing players must meet the cost on the NG card before they may check for completion again. What would be a good NG card?
    I think NG cards should be funny. Maybe a bad weather card. Roger! What should be the Rank of a bad weather card? They can be unranked, and be recycled into the quest deck. Making new icons, designing card. Tweaking. The "Recurring" text is not really legible. I don't think we need it, since a scenario or difficulty mode determines where an NG card go after use. Tweaked! I think it looks good and the other cards should use the same font. The text on top should be centered. I think quest cards (spotlight version) should have the more formal font. May I see a cute version of the ambassador quest card with the cute font? Re-designing a cuter version of the Border Law card with Fuzzy Bubbles font. I think the cuter card is better for the game. Little Red Riding Hood also likes the cuter one more. Could the "Before Autumn Ends" text be bigger? Done! I think the bottom rank letters would look better with a black border. Done! For the quest to be Rank A, it is implied that there is some resistance. I think the text should include the wording of "overcoming resistance". Done! These cards look really good. It is surprising how good the cards can look by just using emoji. StarTree's queue is cleared! Could you continue and make the cards in the ideas section? Um. I think we need to pause and discuss what we need for playtest. We might discover new ideas for the layout. Roger!
    @Guild is now Rank B2.

    Should the guild adopt the same ranking as Arcacian Quest?
    ğŸ”® Quest Ranking
    ğŸ”®Tanya: For Arcacian Quest, the quest rank is based on how much hostility the peacemaker is able to overcome to spread peace. Should we use the same scale on our own Quest Board?
    If we use the same scale, almost all of our activities would be Ranks D, C, B. But switching could direct our attention on how to complete Rank A and S. I think it is against guild policy to say, "Rank S needs to mean such and such". But you are welcome to rank your own chapter that way and others may adopt your same ranking. @Dungeon will switch to that scale. Does it mean adding a new node would no longer be an A? In that scale, it doesn't matter whether you add a node or just add to the same node. It is about how well your content would work against hostility. If I add a tip on happiness without knowing who might read it, what rank would that be? It depends on how well your writing could convince someone against happiness to be happy. I think I understand. If I write them as reminders, without assuming that the viewer is seeking or avoiding happiness, then it would be Rank B (targeted to a neutral audience). Is that correct? If so, there is not much of a change except it is harder to get Rank A or Rank S. That is correct. Then what is Rank D? I thought training is Rank D. Training yourself is Rank D. Reporting for others to learn is at least Rank C. You mean Rank C is a node that would work on a viewer who already has a bias to like the subject, but not on a viewer who has no bias to like the subject. What exactly is a Rank C node? I think it would include nodes with too much assumptions and jargons, or nodes that use language that would turn off a general audience. So if you address the viewer as a "peacemaker", would that be presumptuous and a turn off? Or would that be an effective rapport and make the node Rank B? The effect of that should make the node Rank B, or even Rank A or S. ğŸ’—That is reverse bias. Appeal to Common Decency. I think that skill by itself is Rank A. {"cmd":"url","url":"https://freakonomics.com/podcast/enough-with-the-slippery-slopes/","desc":"ğŸ”—"} If that language makes an addition Rank A, would it be too easy? ğŸ’—I think that level of peacemaking should be accessible. I meant, if we make a knowledge card with the concept of Appeal to Common Decency, would the player hero become Rank A in that skill as soon as they draw it? Knowing it doesn't mean that you would use it. I think when you use it your message still need to be morally sound. Technically peacemaking doesn't mean that you know the correct solution. It could just mean that you de-escalated a conflict so the participants can reach a solution. Then I agree that it could be a common skill for Rank A quests. If the player heroes can do Rank A quest since the first month, there would be no sense of leveling up. The game would feel tedious continuing for 12 months. I don't think that would be the only or even relevant skill in many quests. I think it is strange if we know useful skills but don't teach them from the start. The skill itself should be a freebie. Yes. I think it is worthy as a basic card I want to point out that "Appeal to Common Decency" is not a logical fallacy when it is not being used to assert what is true, but as an assumption of or a plead to the viewer's intent. It is the similar to "innocent until proven guilty." Unless they have said they are not trying to make peace, you assume that they acted thinking that they are trying to make peace. Then you address whether their action helps or obstruct that presumed goal. StarTree could you make a node for this? What should this skill be called? Presumed Goodness? If this is called Presumed Goodness and is Rank A, then Assertive Goodwill is Rank S. Okay. The game will totally break if the player can just get basic Rank S cards. If that is a basic card, it should be unranked, so the player still need to use it to do quests and level up through completing quests. I think the card should be fair and reflect the actual rank of the skill. The fact that it doesn't solve all problems just means the problem has more costs. Is a quest rank card applicable to any skill? If so, just having the skill be Rank S by itself would not make all other skills Rank S. But this skill is so simple and basic, would it be a basic healing skill? I think part of the game should be about the fact that one hero cannot do all the quests. So even if your hero gets that free Rank S skill card, it is not the end of the game because the other heroes don't have that card, and you can't rely on one hero to finish all quests. If the deck is thick, you might not even draw that card. StarTree please make the node and the card. Roger!

    StarTree thinks that the wording is difficult to understand, therefore, even though the skill itself is Rank S, the node is Rank C! I see.

{"name":"Fina","score":"1"}, {"name":"James","score":"1"}, {"name":"V","score":"1"}, {"name":"Casey","score":"1"}, {"name":"Vivi","score":"1"}, {"name":"Sylvia","score":"1"}, {"name":"P4","score":"1"}     Assertive Goodwill is a Cooperative Peacemaking Paradigm tactic that allows progress to be made even if one (or all) party is suspected of wrongdoing or acting with evil or hostile intentions. At the pinnacle of this tactic, you could have multiple evil masterminds each plotting for world domination, but end up saving the world in their combined evil efforts. Assertive Goodwill is done by carefully presume the good intention of others to allow the option to do good without making oneself vulnerable.
    Example 1: Hacking
    A hacker hacks for fun. Instead of persecuting them out of fear of their capability, you invite willing hackers to be isolated to help your society discover its own vulnerability before actual hackers try to hack you for real damage.

    Key Takeaway

    1. The tactic user did not commit to any deceptive act. The hacker knows the reason they are isolated and agrees to do so. They did not round up every hacker. There is a job description and willing hackers applied.
    2. The tactic user may require isolation regardless of whether they believe the hacker is at risk of using their skill to harm society. This makes the tactic user neither naive nor prejudiced.
    3. The path they take helps catch other evil-doers or prevent evil from happening (such as when you now have the only person in the entire world that could hack like that and he is helping you trying to defend from a hacker better than him which in reality does not exist.)
    Example 2: Bomb Threat
    Ann has a legitimate request that is being ignored. A bomb threat happens regarding that request. Bob suspects that Ann committed that bomb threat, and argues that her request should not be heard. However, by hearing her request (which in this case is overdue), the bomb threat with such a motive would be defeated.

    Key Takeaway

    1. While it is true that the bomb threat got people's attention to the issue, the request itself is already a part of a harmless process, therefore no additional restriction or confinement needs to be based on Ann for the hearing.
    2. The use of assertive goodwill in this protects the society from being suspected of being prejudiced against Ann.
    3. The system can still be looking for the bomb threat maker regardless of whether it agrees with the hearing, and agreeing with the hearing does not stop the system from treating Ann as a suspect. The status of Ann being a suspect does not disqualify her from the hearing.
    4. If Ann was not the one making the bomb threat, by using assertive goodwill, the society would prevent itself from exercising further injustice to Ann. Society is not giving up on investigating the bomb threat and has no reason to take the risk of treating Ann with prejudice.
    Example 3: Presumed Peacemaker
    Unless a party has said they are not trying to make peace, assume that they acted with the intention to make peace. Then address whether their action helps or obstruct that presumed goal.

    Key Takeaway

    1. This skill is similar to the concept of "innocent until proven guilty", but takes a step further conceptually that the tactic user is not even trying to judge whether the other party is guilty, but to channel the effort into a better overall outcome.
    Example 4: Not monsters, but heroes
    Early in the design of Arcacian Quest, monster hunting was part of the quests, but we moved away from that concept because in Arcacianism, people are not monsters, but peacemakers of different rank. For example a peacemaker who only cares about their own peace would be rank 6 (conquest). It is not know whether they could change into better peacemakers.

    Key Takeaway

    1. In one way of applying this skill, it breaks down the we versus them argument, and puts everyone on the same scale of peacemaking, where everyone is supposed to try and help each other level up in peacemaking.
    Assertive Goodwill
    Rank S Skill
